awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Collaborative: A Framework for Enhancing the Resilience of Cyber Attack Classification and Clustering Mechanisms
awd_abstract_narration:
Classification and clustering are two important classes of machine learning techniques that have been widely used for cyber defense purposes. However, these mechanisms can be defeated by intelligent evasion attacks, such as Adversarial Machine Learning. Currently, there are no effective countermeasures against these sophisticated attacks. The objective of the project is to investigate effective countermeasures to make classification and clustering mechanisms robust against intelligent evasion attacks. The scientific contributions of the project include advancing our understanding of the feasibility and impact of evasion attacks, and the design of machine learning algorithms that are robust against such attacks. Since machine learning techniques are widely employed in many other areas such as real-world fraud and crime detection, those areas would benefit from this project too. The project will involve PhD students who will directly contribute to the next-generation workforce and will address diversity by involving female students and students from underrepresented groups.

The project plans to achieve its goal by investigating a more powerful class of attacks, called gray-box attacks, than the traditional black-box attacks investigated in the literature. In the gray-box attack model, the attacker can perform all the activities that a defender would normally perform. The project will build a theoretical model and framework for characterizing the vulnerability and resilience of classification and clustering mechanisms with respect to intelligent evasion attacks under the gray-box model, enhance classification and clustering mechanisms to withstand intelligent evasion attacks with quantifiable resilience gains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cyberspace is a virtual universe that is critical to modern society, as many business and personal transactions are conducted online. Like the physical universe, there are many attackers in cyberspace that attempt to steal money and digital assets from innocent people and enterprises, such as Intellectual Properties, compromise citizen's privacy, and wage cyber/information warfare. One major class of cyber attacks is malicious software (malware) which can penetrate any computer or device that is vulnerable. The prevalence of these attacks mandates that we must use Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) techniques as countermeasures against them. However, AI/ML techniques themselves are vulnerable to advanced attacks, meaning that capable attackers (e.g., nation-state or well-funded criminal organizations) can render defensive AI/ML techniques useless, or even allowing these AI/ML techniques to do more harm than good. Effective defenses against these attacks turn out to be an extremely challenging scientific problem. This project significantly advanced the state-of-the-art by proposing new frameworks and methods to enhance the resilience of defensive AI/ML techniques against these attacks, as evidenced by the many (more than 40) technical publications at top-tier journals and conference proceedings. For example, our research won the first place at the world-wide challenge organized by the MIT Lincoln Lab for detecting adversarial malware, which manifests effective countermeasures against the advanced cyber attacks mentioned above. The resulting body of knowledge represents the new state-of-the-art and will inspire many more studies in the future towards ultimately resolving adversarial malware attacks.

The project has had significant broader impacts, including: (i) the resulting techniques and methods published in the many publications mentioned above can be adopted or adapted to commercial products to enhance their resilience against adversarial malware to make cyberspace more secure and trustworthy; (ii) enabled the graduation of five PhD students; (iii) substantial outreach and community presentations to make the general public aware of these cyber threats and best practices to prevent these attacks from succeeding as much as possible; (iv) many students, including undergraduate students, benefited from the project by receiving training based on the knowledge produced by the project; (v) diversity, equity, and inclusiveness were addressed by the investigators as evidenced by a significant number of students from underrepresented groups that have been participating in the research (e.g., the PI is currently supervising six PhD students from underrepresented groups).


Last Modified: 12/24/2022
Modified by: Shouhuai Xu

Cyberspace is a virtual universe that is critical to modern  society, as many business and personal transactions are conducted  online. Like the physical universe, there are many attackers in cyberspace that attempt to steal money and digital  assets from innocent people and enterprises, such as Intellectual Properties, compromise citizen's privacy, and wage cyber/information warfare. One major class of cyber attacks is malicious software (malware) which can penetrate any computer or device that is vulnerable. The prevalence of these attacks mandates that we must use  Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) techniques as countermeasures against them. However, AI/ML techniques themselves are  vulnerable to advanced attacks, meaning that capable attackers (e.g.,  nation-state or well-funded criminal organizations) can render defensive  AI/ML techniques useless, or even allowing these AI/ML techniques to do more harm than good. Effective  defenses against these attacks turn out to be an extremely challenging  scientific problem. This project significantly advanced the state-of-the-art  by proposing new frameworks and methods to enhance the resilience of defensive AI/ML  techniques against these attacks, as evidenced by the many (more than 40) technical  publications at top-tier journals and conference proceedings. For example, our research won the first place  at the world-wide challenge organized by the MIT Lincoln Lab for detecting adversarial malware, which  manifests effective countermeasures against the advanced cyber attacks mentioned above.  The resulting body of knowledge represents the new state-of-the-art  and will inspire many more studies in the future towards ultimately resolving adversarial malware attacks.

The project has had significant broader impacts, including: (i) the resulting techniques and methods published in the many publications mentioned above can be adopted or adapted to commercial products to enhance their resilience against adversarial malware to make cyberspace more secure and trustworthy; (ii) enabled the graduation of five PhD students; (iii) substantial outreach and community presentations to make  the general public aware of these cyber threats and best practices to  prevent these attacks from succeeding as much as possible; (iv) many  students, including undergraduate students, benefited from the project by  receiving training based on the knowledge produced by the project; (v) diversity, equity, and inclusiveness were addressed by the investigators  as evidenced by a significant number of students from underrepresented  groups that have been participating in the research (e.g., the PI is currently supervising six PhD students from underrepresented groups).
